image.altText: police station in adelaides north western surburbs

props.synopsis: The recent death of a police officer at a station in Adelaide's north-western suburbs will be referred to a parliamentary committee into mental health support for the profession.

title.children: SA police officer's death to be referred to parliamentary committee on police mental health

image.altText: A man looks off camera with a considered expression

props.synopsis: The South Australian government has made progress ticking off hundreds of commitments made to taxpayers before the March 2022 election. But it still has a long way to go on key areas like health, integrity and cost-of-living, writes Stephanie Richards and Rory McClaren.

title.children: The biggest political hurdles the SA government will face in 2024

image.altText: A man crying while his family stands next to him

props.synopsis: After his mother put in her two weeks notice on New Year's Eve, the newly minted King Frederik X has been proclaimed monarch of Denmark. Here's everything that happened while you were asleep.

title.children: Denmark's King Frederik wanted a low-key accession. But one thing he saw brought him to tears

image.altText: A group of people on a picnic rug at a beach with drinks in hand.

props.synopsis: From having picnics at the beach near where Mary grew up, to friends of her late mother getting together to mark the milestone, here's how Australians have celebrated the rise of one of their own.

title.children: In the suburb where Mary grew up, locals celebrate the rise of a queen

image.altText: A man in an orange shirt, facing away, sits in a car with the doors open.

props.synopsis: About 70,000 people live in Australia unlawfully. To avoid getting caught, Shan had to go underground — a path he warns no-one should walk.

title.children: When police pulled Shan over, he knew his secret life had just come undone

image.altText: Emergency crews at a Coober Pedy mine site.

props.synopsis: A man trapped down a mine shaft outside Coober Pedy in SA's far north has been taken to hospital with injuries including a fractured leg, after a three-hour rescue operation involving multiple emergency services, authorities say.

title.children: Man rescued from Coober Pedy opal mine after becoming trapped in shaft

image.altText: Emergency workers at a house damaged by a van.

props.synopsis: Two people and a pet dog are lucky to have avoided serious injury, police said, after a van that left the road and "became airborne" smashed through the front window of a house at Nairne in the Adelaide Hills on Saturday night.

title.children: Van that 'became airborne' narrowly misses two people in lounge

image.altText: Uniformed police and detectives outside the Woolworths.

props.synopsis: A Woolworths Metro in the Brisbane suburb of Teneriffe is spray painted with profanities surrounding the Australia Day controversy, with the apartment building above evacuated after a flare was set off.

title.children: 'Boycott Woolies': Brisbane Woolworths vandalised amid Australia Day controversy, apartment evacuated

image.altText: Taylah Preston prepares to hit a tennis ball with a two-handed backhand at the Australian Open.

props.synopsis: Eighteen-year-old Taylah Preston loses in straight sets to 19th seed Elina Svitolina, with 10 other Australians in action on day two of the Australian Open, including world number 10 Alex de Minaur in the night session. Follow live.

title.children: Aussie teen swept aside in grand slam debut on second day at Australian Open

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Storm Hunter breaks her Australian Open duck
We have our first major upset, with the Wimbledon champion knocked out
Aussie Taylah Preston is out in straight sets

image.altText: A photo taken from above of four people doing a jigsaw puzzle together on a black table

props.synopsis: We take a look at some of the latest research on keeping your brain healthy and reducing the risk of dementia.

title.children: Ways to reduce the risk of dementia and improve brain health that may surprise you

props.synopsis: The Critics Choice Awards are underway and it's round two for Barbie vs Oppenheimer. Follow live.

title.children: Barbie leads Oppenheimer with five wins, including for I'm Just Ken, as Beef leads TV awards at Critics Choice

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Sarah Snook wins best actress in a drama series
I'm Just Ken wins best song
Elizabeth Debicki wins best supporting actress in a drama series

image.altText: A composite of Keiran Culkin, Margot Robbie, Sarah Snook and Colman Domingo on the Critics Choice red carpet

props.synopsis: The Critics Choice Awards bring together stars from both television and film, offering up a fashion feast on the red carpet.

title.children: Critics Choice red carpet offers up red roses, golden boots and a really long button-up shirt

image.altText: Chris O'Connell pups his fists as he celebrates winning a point during an Australian Open match.

props.synopsis: At one stage during his injury-disrupted career, Chris O'Connell was cleaning boats at a marina to make a living. He now finds himself entrenched inside the top 100 as he looks to make a deep run at the Australian Open.

title.children: How Chris O'Connell wants to show 30 is the new 20 in the tennis world

image.altText: An Australian male tennis player hits a double-fisted backhand at the 2024 Australian Open.

props.synopsis: It might be modest compared to what Novak Djokovic earns, but Dane Sweeny's payday for making the first round of the Australian Open goes a long way when you're ranked 257 in the world.

title.children: Dane Sweeny shared an Airbnb before his Australian Open debut, such is the cost of being a pro tennis player

image.altText: People mill past Australian Open signage at the beginning of the tournament.

props.synopsis: Freedom of Information documents reveal Victorian taxpayers made two multi-million-dollar support payments to Tennis Australia to cover Australian Open COVID-19 costs.

title.children: Australian Open host kept afloat by $100m taxpayer rescue, documents reveal

image.altText: A large gold symbol featuring two patterned circles next to International Court of Justice written in capital letters

props.synopsis: A compelling legal and public relations battle is underway at the International Court of Justice as two nations battle for reputation and the history books, writes John Lyons.

title.children: The question of genocide in Gaza is a battle for reputation and history

image.altText: Three women cry and embrace at a funeral.

props.synopsis: There were no signs of the conflict letting up on its 100th day with fierce fighting in southern and central Gaza, and warnings from Hamas' armed wing saying many Israeli hostages "may have been killed".

title.children: Hamas warns fate of Israeli hostages unknown as war in Gaza enters 100th day

image.altText: A woman smiles in a large shed in front of a basket of tomatoes.

props.synopsis: With allegations of price gouging levelled at the major supermarkets and an inquiry ongoing, more Australians are seeking other ways to get their groceries.

title.children: Meet the Australians cutting out the supermarket middle-man

image.altText: Frederik and Mary wave happily from a balcony.

props.synopsis: Denmark's longest reigning monarch, Queen Margrethe II, signs the declaration of her abdication, triggering the ascension of her son Prince Frederik and Australian-born Princess Mary.

title.children: Australia's Princess Mary becomes Queen of Denmark with royal proclamation of King Frederik X

image.altText: A person holds the mouth of a catfish open.

props.synopsis: Researchers are trying to figure out what is causing the deaths of the Mary River turtles they have spent years trying to save.

title.children: Probe launched after 'bum-breathing' turtles tracked at faster speeds than they can swim

image.altText: Flames from a bushfire in Bindoon

props.synopsis: One of two emergency bushfires burning north of Perth is downgraded, as firefighters battle several out-of-control blazes north of Perth.

title.children: At least one property destroyed as hundreds of firefighters battle out-of-control blazes north of Perth

image.altText: A person holds an "I voted" sticker

props.synopsis: The first votes of the 2024 US election season will soon be cast. Here's what you need to know about the process that will answer the question: Who will be up against Joe Biden?

title.children: Americans are about to vote but it's not for president. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: A wrought iron sign reading "warmest welcome from Australia's hottest town".

props.synopsis: In the West Australian town of Marble Bar, Sunday was the first day since December 18 with a temperature high below 43 degrees Celsius.

title.children: Australia's 'hottest town' swelters through almost a month of highs above 43 degrees Celsius

image.altText: Dr Ash Gordon wears a white collared shirt and blue blazer and smiles in front of a cream brick wall.

props.synopsis: Ash Gordon, a doctor working in Melbourne's east, has been named as the man found dead on a Doncaster street after a weekend home invasion.

title.children: Tributes for 'well loved, respected' doctor who died after home invasion in Melbourne's east

image.altText: Brisbane inner city suburbs rooftops solar panels

props.synopsis: St Vincent de Paul calls for an urgent shake-up of power bills, warning the cost of Australia's clean energy transition is disproportionately falling on poorer customers.

title.children: Charity warns vulnerable households bearing brunt of green energy schemes

image.altText: A man in his-vis gear walks past an ASX share price board.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market has opened lower to begin the trading week, with energy stocks leading the early gains off the back of higher oil prices, after a mixed session on Wall Street on Friday. Follow live.

title.children: ASX opens lower as energy stocks lead early gains after higher oil prices, December jobs data ahead

Tiwi elders lose cultural heritage case against Santos
US Federal Reserve to cut interest rates in March: Barclays

image.altText: Michelle Yeoh holds a tray with burning incense in it, appearing to provide an offering at a temple, while her eyes are teary.

props.synopsis: New year new content! Here's what's good and new to streaming this month that you might not have heard of yet.

title.children: Huge new Michelle Yeoh series fuses black comedy and martial arts: The best of what to watch this January

image.altText: Director Sofia Coppola, Costume Designer Stacey Battat hold a wedding dress worn by actor Cailee Spaeny who is looking back

props.synopsis: Director Sofia Coppola says Priscilla Presley "goes through moments that every girl goes through as you grow up" in her eponymous new film about Elvis' bride.

title.children: 'I'm sorry she couldn't see it': Sofia Coppola laments Lisa Marie Presley didn't see final film of her mother's story

image.altText: Alex de Minaur points up to the sky

props.synopsis: Is it easier to win your home grand slam than any other major? Some stats suggest that top players are more likely to win at home, but it's not as simple as that, Simon Smale writes.

title.children: It's been 48 years since an Australian man won the Australian Open — can de Minaur break that drought?

image.altText: Rod Laver Arena bathed in sunshine with packed stands

props.synopsis: Here's your comprehensive pocket guide on the first grand slam of the season.

title.children: Want to catch all the action from the Australian Open? Here's where to watch and all the Aussie players in main draw

image.altText: Young people stand near and in a dilapidated home after the Tongan eruption and tsunami.

props.synopsis: Today marks the second anniversary of the Hunga Tonga-Hunga Ha'apai volcano's eruption. Photographer Leki Lao's images were some of the first to emerge from the devastation.

title.children: When a Tongan volcano erupted two years ago, they were cut off from the world. These images were some of the first

image.altText: A blonde girl smiles at the camera sitting ihn a bar with the beach in the background.

props.synopsis: Lillian Reed works six days a week to afford her share of the rent on a Varsity Lakes house she shares with four other people.

title.children: Rents are so high on the Gold Coast some tenants are living with five housemates

image.altText: A small mammal pulling a lever on the puzzle, causing a flap to lift up.

props.synopsis: Bettongs, chuditch, quendas and antechinus as well as possums, skinks, kangaroos and echidnas were put through their paces to see which of our native animals could complete puzzles left in bushland.

title.children: What's the smartest animal in the bush?

image.altText: A waterhole surrounded by rocky cliffs.

props.synopsis: NSW Police say a search for the boy began after he was reported missing on Sunday afternoon.

title.children: Teenage boy dies after reportedly jumping from rock ledge at NSW waterhole

image.altText: A smiling, middle-aged woman leans on a bar beneath a sign that says "Opal Bar".

props.synopsis: During a deadly bushfire crisis last year, the Glengarry Hilton at Grawin Opal Fields threw its doors open to everyone who needed shelter, including the men and women battling the blaze.

title.children: When disaster struck, this pub became much more than a place to have a beer
